Do you want to know a distinguished Madrid restaurant? This the place to come

title_review: Excellent Wine and Cheese Vendor and Tapas Bar!
review_preview: Distinctively Spanish wine and cheese shop cum deli with a tapas restaurant in the back. Walk in and be greeted by a host of Spanish cheeses and meats (Iberico, Chorizo, pate, etc.) available by the kilo with accompanying wines, fruits, nuts, and other items for...
review_full: Distinctively Spanish wine and cheese shop cum deli with a tapas restaurant in the back. Walk in and be greeted by a host of Spanish cheeses and meats (Iberico, Chorizo, pate, etc.) available by the kilo with accompanying wines, fruits, nuts, and other items for your next dinner party or for the roving gourmand. A handful of tables in the front make it a delicatessen where you can get a coffee, pastry, empanada, etc. Deli area quickly fills with an eclectic blend of neighborhood characters (the struggling writer, the morning newspaper-reader, the older Spanish gentleman holding court in the back, etc.).  Friends who are serious about cheese tell me that their selection is simply excellent and among the best in Madrid. I tried of couple of the pasteurized Spanish goat cheeses and they were outstanding. Walk towards the back and find a full wine/coffee bar and dinning area comfortably seating perhaps 20 or so people, simply but charmingly decorated. Any of the deli items are available as well as a series of hot dishes and salads as well as tapas staples like tostas with anchovies. I sat in the back and ordered a spicy chorizo, some goat cheese, a glass of red wine, and had my lunch. Far too much meat for me to eat though, should have only ordered the half portion. Meal was under 20 Euros including wine and a generous helping of Chorizo de Leon (would have paid $20 alone in the States for a portion of that size).  Staff are friendly and remember you but can get slammed when both the front and back of house are full so those wishing a quick meal stay in the front as the back slows down during peak times. The Calle Atocha area is a poor area for restaurants but this is absolutely the exception and if you love wine and cheese (or good Iberico) stop by. Credit Cards are accepted. Open both early and late.

title_review: Great place to be introduced to Spanish wine and cheese
review_preview: Casa Gonzalez is one of my favorite, standby restaurants to take visiting friends and family to as an introduction to Spanish cured meats and cheese. It has the charming interior and exterior of a traditional Spanish restaurant/cafe. There is a decent variety of things to...
review_full: Casa Gonzalez is one of my favorite, standby restaurants to take visiting friends and family to as an introduction to Spanish cured meats and cheese. It has the charming interior and exterior of a traditional Spanish restaurant/cafe. There is a decent variety of things to try apart from their specialty of cheese. I've even been with a vegetarian and we managed to eat very well. I like the feeling of flexibility offered at Casa Gonzalez--you can drop in for a light meal of wine, cheese and tapas or end up eating a hearty meal. The waiters are always very friendly and helpful, and I've never experienced a great pressure to order more if I didn't want to. The price is normal; I wouldn't say it's a crazy bargain, but most items are priced fairly considering the atmosphere.

title_review: Great Madrileño dishes at de Vacas
review_preview: Viuda de Vacas is a fine example of a traditional restaurant , serving no nonsense food in nice surroundings with friendly staff in a great atmosphere using seasonal produce.Set in La Latina, Vacas is very homely , looks like you would expect an old...
review_full: Viuda de Vacas is a fine example of a traditional restaurant , serving no nonsense food in nice surroundings with friendly staff in a great atmosphere using seasonal produce. Set in La Latina, Vacas is very homely , looks like you would expect an old Spanish restaurant to be but serving some great Madrileño dishes. Ordered some vermut to start which came with a plate of deliciously juicy , tasty black olives and a bread basket. Started with a plate of wonderfully crunchy croquetas containing a creamy light ham filling complimented with a simple tomato salad, just perfect! Mains were slightly bigger than expected but packed a punch, my morcillo estofado ( stewed beef shin) was served with in a rich onion sauce and came off the bone easily, beautiful tender meat, quails stuffed with paté and mushrooms was awesome, served with crispy little fries but just too much and if bones aren’t your thing best to avoid . Other diners’ meals all looked great too. Wine selection was good and pretty reasonable, no room for a desert but a free shot of digestif was appreciated from the host, total including the water and wine came to €70 which was decent value considering the quality of the food and cooking. Staff were very friendly and hospitable and English menus are available if your Spanish is not up to scratch. Very good choice for excellent home style cooking and enjoyable meal if in the area . Lots of little bars in La Latina so go wander after your meal and explore.

review_full: My wife's brother (who lives in the area) took 8 of us to this restaurant at 21.30hrs on a Friday night. It's one of his favourite restaurants in Madrid. We didn't have a reservation and as we were quite a large party we had two tables put together downstairs, which is a lovely brick lined room. The owners are very friendly and accommodating. The waitress spoke Spanish and English with us. The food was excellent... tempura aubergines, squid-in-ink croquettes, fresh hake, breaded escalope, roast ham and mashed potato and the most tender steak! Situated in La Latina area means that this place isn't a tourist hotspot (we were the only English people in there) and the prices are very reasonable - 240 Euros for 8 people with starters, main courses, couple of puddings and a few bottles of wine. They also gave us all complementary digestifs. Definitely coming back here next time we're in Madrid.

We also like the wine recommendations very much!

title_review: A terrific wee place for authentic country cooking
review_preview: Can very much recommend this family owned and run gem of a restaurant and bar in La Latina. The menu offers a fair choice of first and second courses plus desserts and a small wine list. Food and wine are unpretentious but what you get...
review_full: Can very much recommend this family owned and run gem of a restaurant and bar in La Latina. The menu offers a fair choice of first and second courses plus desserts and a small wine list. Food and wine are unpretentious but what you get is great well cooked food and a good choice of Spanish wines that suit the home style cooking. I loved the bean and chorizo soup and the shin beef stew waa perfectly cooked, adding its juices to the potatoes and carrots. The beef or oxtail stew can be complemented by a well priced rioja, or the adventurous might choose the Portugese style cod or even the tripe. Dining is outside on a quiet corner of La Latina, in the ground floor bar/restaurant or in the cellar.

review_full: We went here for lunch on a Sunday. They were quite busy but we managed to get a table outside without waiting. We had to wait a little while to order and then to get our bill at the end, but the food arrived quickly! I asked about gluten-free options, and as well as being knowledgeable about what they have (including gluten-free buns), the waiter also brought me the allergen menu to check. This made it easier when ordering, as I knew which sauces etc. I could eat. I went for a BBQ burger, which was mainly gluten-free (only 1 mayo that wasn't, so asked for it without) as long as served with a gluten-free bun. The chips are also suitable for coeliacs - and super yummy! The whole meal was just right, full of flavour with the burger cooked exactly how I'd asked it to be. The GF bun was a bit crumbly (as per usual) but tasted good and held together long enough to eat, which is an achievement! Also very good if you're not coeliac, my boyfriend loved his burger too!

title_review: Very slow service and mediocre burger. Pass.
review_preview: Went there alone  for lunch and sat at one of the tall tables closest to the bar, facing it. Despite this, it took them almost 10 minutes to take my order (as I was about to walk out). It then took over 20 minutes for...
review_full: Went there alone for lunch and sat at one of the tall tables closest to the bar, facing it. Despite this, it took them almost 10 minutes to take my order (as I was about to walk out). It then took over 20 minutes for my burger to come. The burger was OK, but nothing to write home about. Meat wasn't bad, but not particularly juicy or tasty. If Madrid wasn't full of gourmet burger joints, you might have a reason to come eat here, but there are so many better burgers in the center of Madrid that there is no reason to.  The home made chips were quite nice.

title_review: Most tasty street food we ever had in Spain
review_preview: In one of the June weekends in the Rastro flea market of Madrid, we walked up Calle de Carlos Arniches, bumping into the longest queue for people trying to get food during our Spainish trip. This is El Capricho Extremeño. Operated even more efficiently than...
review_full: In one of the June weekends in the Rastro flea market of Madrid, we walked up Calle de Carlos Arniches, bumping into the longest queue for people trying to get food during our Spainish trip. This is El Capricho Extremeño.   Operated even more efficiently than McDonald, a variety of toasts/tapas, with chicken empanadas, shrimp in olive oil, Jamos ham, mushrooms (very recommended), squid, baby eel, .... are all good, in big portions and priced in the amazing range of 2-2.5 euros only, each.    Imagine in the center of Madrid, paying 5 euros to get my stomach solidly stuffed and feeling truly satisfied, by a streeet food standard. All we gave up was a sitting chair.

review_preview: I have been to this restaurant more than a dozen times - I make it a point to have one meal here when I'm in Madrid. I have recommended the restaurant to local Madrileno friends, and they agree this is a place where you can...
review_full: I have been to this restaurant more than a dozen times - I make it a point to have one meal here when I'm in Madrid. I have recommended the restaurant to local Madrileno friends, and they agree this is a place where you can have great traditional Spanish dishes. For my palate, I like their more subtle flavors - not too strong or salty compared to other restaurants. My favorites - calamares in su tinta, rabo de toro, and callos a la Madrilena. Because they are not as centrally loacted, unless it's a weekend, you typically can walk in without a reservation. Definitely worth the 15-minute walk from Sol.

review_preview: We visited this burger restaurant on a Friday night after trying to get in some other restaurants and failing to do so (Madrid gets so busy during the weekend!). And oh boy, I am so happy we came across Burnout.The decoration is American 70s,...
review_full: We visited this burger restaurant on a Friday night after trying to get in some other restaurants and failing to do so (Madrid gets so busy during the weekend!). And oh boy, I am so happy we came across Burnout. The decoration is American 70s, it's like going back in time with a good touch. They even have books dating back to the 50s in Spain. They offer salads and different types of burgers. I went for the Burnout Smokin burger and I would totally recommend it, it was well done as I ordered and had an amazing flavour. The bun was sweet and unique and the mixture of ingredients and sauces made this a stunning burger. Your burger comes with a side of fries, which differ from those you find at fast food restaurants, this ones had a more natural feeling. As a treat for dessert we ordered a couple of Guiness cakes, which are apparently a thing in Madrid but I had never seen in London before. I loved the flavour and the moist texture!  Overall, a great experience, I would definitely recommend and I would come back in future trips to Madrid.

title_review: Fast food at its best: best ingredients, rapidly handed out for little money
review_preview: If you go to el Rastro (big multi-street flea market) you should drop by this place, which only sells tostas (toasted slice of white bread with a bit of squished ripe fresh tomato and the topping of your liking and a good drizzle of olive...
review_full: If you go to el Rastro (big multi-street flea market) you should drop by this place, which only sells tostas (toasted slice of white bread with a bit of squished ripe fresh tomato and the topping of your liking and a good drizzle of olive oil) on Sundays, while the flea market is on. Very yummy, very Spanish, very fast (after you have reached the sometimes very long queue), and very cheap for the size and freshness. I normally take jamon con queso (air-dried ham and cheese) or pulpo a la Gallega (cooked squid slices in olive oil and red bell pepper powder), but they have all different tastes... Take many tissues for the dripping olive oil!

title_review: A little gem still going strong - terrific lunch
review_preview: A couple friends and I were delighted to find this neighborhood restaurant was still open well over 10 years after having last been.  It's a family-run place (one of the servers is the daughter of the owner) with fantastic typical Spanish fare along with elevated...
review_full: A couple friends and I were delighted to find this neighborhood restaurant was still open well over 10 years after having last been. It's a family-run place (one of the servers is the daughter of the owner) with fantastic typical Spanish fare along with elevated versions of the classics. For example, the roast quail stuffed with foie...incredible. We also shared a starter of grilled asparagus that were almost an inch thick in diameter and finished with typically great Spanish olive oil and giant salt flakes. So delicious. Service was friendly and helpful and prices very reasonable. Unfortunately the few outside tables were taken when we arrived, but we got to sit in the cellar, which was beautiful in its own right. If you're in La Latina and looking for a quiet and authentic experience, head here.

title_review: Excellent Burger and Nachos, great place to eat . . .
review_preview: We live in Madrid and I´ve tried almost all of the well-known and not so well-known hamburger places in Madrid and was pretty much resigned to one place where I felt like I could consistently get an American style hamburger.  We happened by this place...
review_full: We live in Madrid and I´ve tried almost all of the well-known and not so well-known hamburger places in Madrid and was pretty much resigned to one place where I felt like I could consistently get an American style hamburger. We happened by this place today and I´m glad we gave it a try. This is a great burger, a fun place to eat and its in a wonderful location. Calle Fuencarral is a great street for shopping and watching people. The fact that this restaurant has nice outdoor seating makes it even nicer. But the food is the best part. I was very surprised at the quality of my cheeseburger and the fries. My wife tried the chicken tenders and they were okay, but not something I would order again. We tried the nachos as an appetizer and they were very good. All in all a nice eating experience and worth a return visit. Service was friendly and prompt and the outdoor seating is very comfortable. I asked about making a burger a favorite way of mine and they said they would be happy to do it. They have additional seating inside and a larger seating area downstairs. Restrooms were clean and they had paper towels, which is always nice. To top it off, they take Amex. I think I can count on one hand the number of restaurants in Madrid that take Amex. Another plus in my book. They open at 1:00 pm.

title_review: Best burger by far - service could improve
review_preview: For a restaurant that's only 5 months old, Burnout is doing amazingly well and rightly so. The burger is one of the best I've had (and I have made my way around the London burger scene) - great patty to bun ratio. Although there's slightly...
review_full: For a restaurant that's only 5 months old, Burnout is doing amazingly well and rightly so. The burger is one of the best I've had (and I have made my way around the London burger scene) - great patty to bun ratio. Although there's slightly too much bread, it does mean that your last bite isn't just meat being held together by two tiny slivers of bread.  The menu is very simple burger-wise but oh-so-tasty. The only downside of tonight was the service - it seems that a lot of the waiting staff are new, but very optimistic. This did mean that our order "got lost" and we waited 25mins before we had to ask the manager what happened. He was very apologetic and gave us our milkshakes on the house which was very kind - however not before I shot him an extremely hangry look. I would definitely return, if only to have that burger once more, hopefully by then they'll have got their organisation skills sorted.

review_preview: It is eating at places like these that remind me of how delicious home cooked meals are! I ate the ox tail and my friend ate the tripe. Cooked and seasoned to perfection. The flavors are well balanced as sometimes those flavors can be overpowering...
review_full: It is eating at places like these that remind me of how delicious home cooked meals are! I ate the ox tail and my friend ate the tripe. Cooked and seasoned to perfection. The flavors are well balanced as sometimes those flavors can be overpowering but they were paired with the perfect veggies! I highly recommend the chicken soup. However this is not your typical soup, it is just broth with sparing chicken pieces and a little bit of polenta at the bottom. I can guarantee you have never tasted something like this! The server was so patient in explaining the menu and even brought is out small sausages for us to try so we could have something to enjoy while our food came out. Thank you to the wonderful staff and chefs that made this dining experience a glorious one!

title_review: Most Arrogant Restaurant Establishment---But Cannot Be in Madrid Without Passing By
review_preview: This establishment only opens on Sunday mornings. The rest of the week, they are closed. Despite their opening hours, the only libation served is alcoholic: beer, wine, and sangria (this is Spain, after all). No chairs here. After being served (it is pay-as-you-order), you are...
review_full: This establishment only opens on Sunday mornings. The rest of the week, they are closed. Despite their opening hours, the only libation served is alcoholic: beer, wine, and sangria (this is Spain, after all). No chairs here. After being served (it is pay-as-you-order), you are told to move away from the bar and go elsewhere to consume your tosta. No establishment could be more snooty. Yet I cannot come to Madrid without a pilgrimage to Capricho. Hence, I try and make sure my Madrid sojourn always involves a Sunday. Capricho is a family affair. As the name suggests, the proprietor hails from Extremadura, the southwestern autonomous community of Spain. Ramon the father is a bald-headed man given to non-stop histrionics. He is the life of the party. His wife and daughters help him manage the crowd and the extraordinary demand for their tostas. Tostas are slices of chapata bread onto which heavenly goodies have been piled on---like octopus, ham, bacalo, cheese, gambas...you name it. All finished off with a drizzle of the finest olive oil from, of course, Extremadura. 2 euros a pop. Not bad at all. Oh, when it is cold they serve a delightful broth for 1.50 euro, and also gazpacho...so it is not just alcohol after all. No worries, when you need coffee there are many bars around.

Just wonderful to lunch after...
review_full: Good typical Spanish food from the Extremadura region, with nice tapas and simple dishes. Migas (bread crumbs fried and combined with vegetables, great!), cheese (Torta from La Serena, fantastic), great iberico ham, chorizo, cured lomo, olives and other great delicacies. Just wonderful to lunch after a tour on the Rastro on the weekends.

My favorite tostas are the setas, smoked salmon and ofcourse you can never go wrong with jamon.

title_review: A great place to taste real and delicious spanish Tostas!
review_preview: El Capricho is a great place to taste real and great Tostas in Madrid. It is a small "bar/restaurant" near la Latina. The person that takes care is the owner and I always received great treat from all the people that attends there. Great service...
review_full: El Capricho is a great place to taste real and great Tostas in Madrid. It is a small "bar/restaurant" near la Latina. The person that takes care is the owner and I always received great treat from all the people that attends there. Great service however be patient because sometime is a bit crowded and you have to wait. In this place there are not tables so, the tipical is to go outside and sit at the streets and enjoy the environment (specially if its a Sunday of El Rastro market). This tostas are worth it, you will find of Tortilla de Patatas, Salmon, Pulplo (octopus), Cheese with Jam, and more.. but my favorite is Gulas. It is a must! The best part is that they are quite cheap. The only thing is that I am not sure if they open everyday of which is the schedule, I always go on Sunday when is El Rastro!!

review_preview: We had lunch at this cafe. It has very limited hours so patrons need to be careful. It is open from 1.30pm to 4.30pm but really closes at 4.00pm, We tried to have a meal at 4.15 and there was really on a couple of...
review_full: We had lunch at this cafe. It has very limited hours so patrons need to be careful. It is open from 1.30pm to 4.30pm but really closes at 4.00pm, We tried to have a meal at 4.15 and there was really on a couple of dishes left on the menu which were available. We persisted and went back, and it was worth returning. We had the 11 euro menu, and the quality of the food was very good. The courses were good sized portions without be big.  The quality of the food was particularly good. My partner has sole which was a fish casserole. It was quite exceptional. We did notice on our last unsuccessful visit that the fish on guests' plates also look magnificent. This cafe is tucked away off Calle de Toledo, near Plaza Mayor but times we have been in the venue, the cafe was full. It suggested to us that the cafe relies on a regular Spanish clientele, although the staff were most accommodating in interpreting the menu into English for us. The staff were very helpful and friendly, particularly with respect to our very limited understanding of Spanish. El Capricho Extremeno has a particularly Spanish feel about it, from its decorations to the way that guests were obviously enjoying companionship with food and drink. It was as if we were dining with the locals.

title_review: Better, and far older, than it seems...
review_preview: The Taberna Alatriste can seem at first sight to be something of a themed restaurant with its sometimes over-the-top referecnes to Captain Alatriste, main character in a series of famous novels - and a film - written by Arturo Perez-Reverte. However, it actually is built...
review_full: The Taberna Alatriste can seem at first sight to be something of a themed restaurant with its sometimes over-the-top referecnes to Captain Alatriste, main character in a series of famous novels - and a film - written by Arturo Perez-Reverte. However, it actually is built on the site - and incorporates original elements - of the real Tavern of the Turk which features in the novels. Excellent food - especially the lamb dishes - and wine - especially the Emilio Moro from Ribera del Duero. A favourite when in the city.

review_preview: While in Madrid it was my husbands birthday so having read the reviews we booked a table at this restaurant. The restaurant itself is absolutely amazing. The history of the building is fascinating and the decor was sympathetic to the history. However the food was...
review_full: While in Madrid it was my husbands birthday so having read the reviews we booked a table at this restaurant. The restaurant itself is absolutely amazing. The history of the building is fascinating and the decor was sympathetic to the history.  However the food was a bit of a let down. We decided to share a starter and had the ham croquettes. A pile of about 10 of them arrived with not a single bit of garnish. They were tasty but a little uninspiring.  I ordered the suckling pig which came with sliced potatoes but not a green vegetable in sight. There was a little bit of meat juice on the plate which prevented the whole dish from being completely dry. My husband ordered the lamb fest. Again with sliced potato’s. A pile of about 8 mini lamb chops in the middle of the plate. No sauce whatsoever. So they were very dry.  We didn’t order a pudding but they bought deep fried donuts free with the coffee. They were also very dry and inedible. With a bottle of red wine for my husband and 2 glasses of white for me the bill came to €110.  Quite disappointed and will not go back on our next visit to Madrid.

Two days before of our visit, we tried to make a reservation and here comes our serious disappointment. The only phone number was either busy or without anybody answering and moreover without any possibility to leave a message. After more than 30 calls ( my mobile might prove this ) we sent an e- mail following the suggestion of their web. Once done, we did not receive any answer back with the typical message giving any reason explaining that there are holidays or another more tragic responses. The chosen date at the time we made our reservation, we went to their premises and.....it was closed. No advice, no message, no signal . Another customer was suffering at the same time this circumstance and we could not understand the lack of respect to the customers when the day and the time were published as open in the web. It is not acceptable closing a business so customer oriented as a restaurant is without any notice with a proven diffusion in advance to the closure. I am fully convinced that there will be a good reason to close but NOT without a notice to the customers. Let me repeat, it is not acceptable!!!! And thus my rating is as mentioned.

review_full: We chose dinner at Cachivache because it was not too far from our hotel on the northern side of Madrid. Its ranking is probably based on its location, that it is not in a highly touristy part of Madrid, but if you happen to be in this area, I would highly recommend this restaurant. 5 of us ate dinner with 2 bottles of wine and multiple tapas for around 200 euro. Let me say that the octopus was the most tender and flavorful octopus that I have ever had in the world. We loved it so much that we had every octopus dish on the menu. Many of the meals were served with variety of potatoes prepared in different ways, roasted, fried, shredded, all delicious. The tuna tartare is flavorful with a little acidic bite to it. The chicken liver pate is on a bed of julienned peppers and a hard cracker.

title_review: Authentic, Delicious - a Seafood Lovers Paradise!
review_preview: I first visited Casa Adriana with Spanish (actually, Miguel is Galician!) friends over five years ago and have been back to have many memorable meals here.  This restaurant is 'old school' and completely authentic.  The fish and seafood is impeccably fresh and simply cooked, so...
review_full: I first visited Casa Adriana with Spanish (actually, Miguel is Galician!) friends over five years ago and have been back to have many memorable meals here. This restaurant is 'old school' and completely authentic. The fish and seafood is impeccably fresh and simply cooked, so that the quality shines through. If you are adventurous, try the local delicacy :percebes (goose barnacles). They taste like a cross between a mussel and a clam - sweet, salty and deliciously fiddly! Gambas (shrimp) a la Plancha - amazing, And my favourite, the most Galcian of all dishes: pulpo a la Gallego - melt in the mouth slices of octopus drizzled with olive oil,salt and pimenton (paprika) - sublime. Ask for a bottle of ice cold Albarino and you can't go wrong. It is off the beaten track, and very 'untouristy' as a result (and they don't speak much English), but if you are after the real thing in Madrid, this is the place to go.

title_review: local cuisine from the north of Spain
review_preview: Good restaurant near the city centre. The dishes served here are originally from Asturias (northern region of Spain) so you can find a piece of it in Madrid to enlarge the variety of spanish products in your "to-taste" list. From the typical natural cider to...
review_full: Good restaurant near the city centre. The dishes served here are originally from Asturias (northern region of Spain) so you can find a piece of it in Madrid to enlarge the variety of spanish products in your "to-taste" list. From the typical natural cider to its outstanding Cabrales (blue cheese). It is a place where the best option is to share the dishes and try as many as possible because all of them are delicious (specially the fabada and cachopo). I would recommend to go early, otherwise it will be packed. If you are lucky enough to get a table, it will be worth it!!

review_preview: If  you want a fancy place, where you can run into some fashion chick, and dont care what you are eating. THIS IS NOT YOUR PLACEIf you want to have an extraordinary experience, where the real Sicilian food is served from the bottom of...
review_full: If you want a fancy place, where you can run into some fashion chick, and dont care what you are eating. THIS IS NOT YOUR PLACE If you want to have an extraordinary experience, where the real Sicilian food is served from the bottom of the Chef's heart, THIS IS CLEARLY YOUR PLACE. This is the third restaurant that I know Alfredo has initiated in Madrid and althought the previous two were great, this has the real touch, personal, intimate and incredible cuisine run by Aflredo and his wife. Dont bother checking the menu, the best thing you can say is Alfredo, bring me whatever you feel like it.  I may have eaten in this restaurant and in the previous two, maybe 30 times, and never have repeated the same dish. Alfredo's dishes are endless and you should not feel constraint by a simple printed menu. And remember you are paying for the food, not for the fancy place (which is not) or for the fancy furniture (which is not). Dont expect anything but a simple but authentic place, with no aspirations, but were you will be eating the best Italian food in town. as to the price, you can be paying something between 30 and 50€ but you eat much much better than in a number of Italians where you pay way over 80€

review_preview: My girlfriend and I went to this hip little restaurant for Thanksgiving to give thanks to the bounty of restaurants that proliferate the capital, and believe me we were not disappointed.  Let me get right to the details.We opened with the red tuna tartar...
review_full: My girlfriend and I went to this hip little restaurant for Thanksgiving to give thanks to the bounty of restaurants that proliferate the capital, and believe me we were not disappointed. Let me get right to the details. We opened with the red tuna tartar with a subtle ali-oli sauce on top and toasted bread with olive oil. Spectacular and fresh! The size of the plate for the price is a steal. We continued with Galician octopus, which was succulent and melted in your mouth. These first two plates were accompanied with a glass of Ribeiro and a glass of Albarino; both were elegant and refreshing, especially the Albarino, which for my tastes can sometimes be a bit too sweet. Then we ordered the tacos, which were the only thing I would order again. They were tasty but didn't stack up to the first two. It was our mistake. We then ordered a bottle of the Hisan, a young Ribera del Duero for 10,50, which was light but well rounded. The plate of the night was the oxtail rice with boletus. It was out of this world delicious. To finish a fantastic evening, we ordered the chocolate cake, which is a bit like a cheese cake brownie. It was served with raspberries on top and a little white chocolate reduction on the side. It was completely over the top. The service was attentive and friendly. I highly recommend this place to have a few tapas or go all out like we did and try several different plates. We are already looking forward to going back.

title_review: Outstanding traditional cuisine in a beautiful setting
review_preview: Casa Hortensia is in a high building, with the restaurant in the second floor and the bar in the third. My review is about the bar, which serves tapas and a daily menu. The daily menu has several excellent choices that vary daily, at a...
review_full: Casa Hortensia is in a high building, with the restaurant in the second floor and the bar in the third. My review is about the bar, which serves tapas and a daily menu. The daily menu has several excellent choices that vary daily, at a very reasonable price if you eat in the high tables --in a cozy and pretty setting. The larger dinning room charges more, although still reasonably. The food is traditional from Asturias --which has an outstanding gastronomy, with the classic "fabes" --white beans and excellent fish. Casa Hortensia offers one of the best representations of that cuisine I am aware of.

title_review: Come for the negroni, stay for the boquerones
review_preview: The negronis here are spectacularly potent. The first one I ever had was overpowering, but I have come to enjoy the mix of vermouth (from a tap!), gin, a splash of soda and a dash of campari. While I am not usually a fan, the...
review_full: The negronis here are spectacularly potent. The first one I ever had was overpowering, but I have come to enjoy the mix of vermouth (from a tap!), gin, a splash of soda and a dash of campari. While I am not usually a fan, the boquerones in vinegar are amazing. Deliciously fresh and firm anchovies in a delicious vinegar. Pop one on top of a crunchy potato chip and you are golden! Oh, and the bar itself is a very cool, historic location that has been in the family for a few generations. I highly recommend this place.

Having just come from a typical "Brits abroad" group trip to Barcelona, I was excited to try some real Spanish food and boy, this blew me away. Furthermore, there is an amazing selection of wines to choose from. I am going to stop there and let you try for yourself. Highly recommended restaurant run by great people.

review_preview: We chose this restaurant based on the recommendation of a friend who used to live in Madrid. We mainly wanted to try the fabada which was delicious as expected and did not disappoint. For our second course, we had chosen the merluza a la romana...
review_full: We chose this restaurant based on the recommendation of a friend who used to live in Madrid. We mainly wanted to try the fabada which was delicious as expected and did not disappoint. For our second course, we had chosen the merluza a la romana but it was taking forever to arrive at our table. When we finally asked the waiter about it, he brought us a dish of lukewarm (bordering on room temperature) fish chunks and potatoes. I immediately told him the food was not hot and he basically said it was supposed to be served that way. I'm sure the food had been sitting forgotten for 10-15 minutes. We ended up leaving most of it. It's a shame that a restaurant with such a good reputation did not choose to make the situation right for us. At nearly €25 a plate, this fish should have been impeccable. We will not be returning to this restaurant.

title_review: It doesn't come much better than this!
review_preview: I was in Madrid for a few days attending a conference.  This restaurant came recommended by one of the conference hoists and I'm so glad we took the advice.  What a fantastic restaurant, simply divine food. There were 8 of us dining on a Thursday...
review_full: I was in Madrid for a few days attending a conference. This restaurant came recommended by one of the conference hoists and I'm so glad we took the advice. What a fantastic restaurant, simply divine food.  There were 8 of us dining on a Thursday night. We made a reservation for 21:30 but it was not needed which is quite surprising, you would think a restaurant this good would be packed every night. Service was very good and friendly, even though there was not much English being understood by the waiters. They do have English menus though, which made things a little easier.  We had a huge serving of bread with a blue cheese dip to start with. This was followed by a selection of tapas which included: artichokes which were done with ham; a simply amazing omelette made from ham, sausage and tuna - which looks and tastes nothing like an omelette, but is simply divine, I think this is the house tortilla, a hake omelette - which is more like a what you would expect from a tortilla; and the Hake's Napa with fries. We had a selection of deserts, all were great, but I had the Santiago Cake (Almond tort).  Everything was simply fantastic, all the food was done to perfection. We had several bottles of red wine to wash it all down with and quite a few coffees. We were given a selection of complimentary after dinner spirits at the end of the meal. The whole thing came to €45 per head which we all thought was very reasonable. I don't think I've ever gone to a restaurant with a group before where everyone absolutely loved everything. Would I come here again, absolutely yes, I would happily visit Madrid again just to dine here again!

review_preview: I recently took my friend to this restaurant for a traditional sunday dinner. We have no reservation, however they were able to accommodate us after a period of 15-20 minutes. This restaurant was recommended to us by the local senoras in malasana and was told...
review_full: I recently took my friend to this restaurant for a traditional sunday dinner. We have no reservation, however they were able to accommodate us after a period of 15-20 minutes. This restaurant was recommended to us by the local senoras in malasana and was told this is an excellent restaurant for traditional asturian dishes.  Well, this is my personal opinion. The place was very busy and all the tables were taken. We settled for a salad as starter to share. We weren't very hungry as we stop by mercado de san anton for a bit of galician marisco y pescado tapas and a glass of albarino. The blue cheese spread for the bread was excellent. The salad is just like any normal salad with tuna, tomato, onion, lettuce. However because my companion was in the mood for lamb chop cutlet, we settled for the lamb chop. Before ordering i asked the waiter whether the portion was big or not. He told me the portion was small, so we ordered 2 lamb chop dinners. When the order arrived i noticed the portion were quite large. With all the reputation i heard about this restaurant, i was quite disappointed when i bit into the baby lamb chop cutlet. All the cutlets were overcooked. Yes the cutlets were delicious if not for the overcooking. Of course i did not say anything as i did not want to create a scene. I do speak spanish and my companion is spanish. Maybe it is a once off thing as there were very busy. However i was extremely disappointed. I did not bother to order the dessert. My companion ordered the dessert and it was excellent. Will i go back to this restaurant? The answer is either no or maybe. I do not mind paying for expensive dinner as long as the food is good. But i do mind when the food is not to expectation. Despite all the good reviews in tripadisor i wondered what is all the hype about this restaurant.

title_review: Large Galician restaurant, quite formal atmosphere, good food but overpriced for what it is
review_preview: From the outside, Casa Hortensia does not look much like a restaurant, more like an office building. However, the famous Galician eating temple occupies two floors. We were recommended to go there as one of the best in town. And in fact, the Galician cuisine...
review_full: From the outside, Casa Hortensia does not look much like a restaurant, more like an office building. However, the famous Galician eating temple occupies two floors. We were recommended to go there as one of the best in town. And in fact, the Galician cuisine is famous in Spain and at Casa Hortensia, they serve some of the most typical dishes. This includes bean stew, fried fish, pulpo a la gallega (of course) and cidre, the famous apple wine from Northern Spain. Our lunch was really a different experience compared to most regular restaurants. However, the atmosphere is a bit formal.

review_preview: While in Madrid last October I went to Casa Hortensia for a business dinner (was recommended by locals) and was not disappointed. I have been many times to Madrid for business and being European myself I love great food and wine. Everything from beginning to...
review_full: While in Madrid last October I went to Casa Hortensia for a business dinner (was recommended by locals) and was not disappointed. I have been many times to Madrid for business and being European myself I love great food and wine. Everything from beginning to end was perfect and we were a large group! The food is Galician. We started with some excellent and misc. appetizer: tortilla, jamon (Spanish cured ham), tuna belly, clams, cheese and everything was well presented, fresh and promptly served. All the main dishes we ordered (beware of the large size) we also excellent. I personally had the filet mignon with French fries and the quality of the meat was top. Everyone on my party whether they ordered fish or meat were impressed with the quality of the food and its presentation. For dessert I had the lemon sorbet and the other desserts (we shared a few) were excellent too. Their wine selection is also great. The service was very efficient even after midnight :-) Overall a great dinner and experience. The restaurant setting itself is comfortable and allows for private and romantic dinners. Will come back when in Madrid!

review_full: The atmosphere was somewhat lacking with only 3 tables occupied on a Wednesday evening. However, the service was agreeable and food more so. Beware of large portions, if you're not overly hungry I would share one starter and one main course between two people. My boyfriend and I shared one starter, the tortilla de la casa, which was very good. Then we each ordered a main course of which we both had to leave almost half on the plate due to the portion size. I had the merluza a la sidra which was cooked perfectly, very white moist fish. My boyfriend had the fabes con perdiz which was also good. Overall, it was an enjoyable experience. Hearty homemade food, but not the best Asturian restaurant in Madrid, as some comments claim. Far from it, in fact, but not bad and worth a visit. Especially as it is fairly priced.

review_full: We chanced upon this restaurant as we were looking for dinner one evening. Steaks on another table looked good, so we stopped and were glad we did. We all had a different meal - steak, lamb chops and lamb shank - and all were well cooked and delicious. The sides - roasted red peppers, salad and big, chunky fries - were also good. Well worth a mention is the wonderful appetizer they sent out with our drinks - crispy fried pork belly pieces. Very tasty and very moreish! There was also a quite decent wine list, and we had a very good bottle (or 2) of Spanish red to accompany our meal.

review_preview: The ambiance at this restaurant is amazing. We were seated downstairs and I was snapping pictures all the way down. Upon arrival we were served delicious bread, olives, and other condiments. The staff was very nice & attentive to our needs. The menus were wrapped...
review_full: The ambiance at this restaurant is amazing. We were seated downstairs and I was snapping pictures all the way down. Upon arrival we were served delicious bread, olives, and other condiments. The staff was very nice & attentive to our needs. The menus were wrapped in a leather scroll type way which was cool! The menu itself is not real extensive, my friend & I chose a fish to share as did several other ladies in our party. We were all a bit put off with the head being still on the fish (even after living in Asia for 3 years I just can't get used to this). My fish was ok, but I felt that it was swimming in too much butter/oil. The suckling pig was amazingly good, the best we had during our trip! The veggies we ordered were overcooked in my opinion, but were ok. The house table wine & the bread & condiments were all very good & we definitely didn't leave hungry! I would return to this restaurant, but I would stick to the suckling pig next time.

review_preview: I was intrigued by the name of this restaurant; Captain Alatriste is a character in a series of books - historical fiction.  He is a swordsman who is for hire, and also will train you; kind of a Paladin like character. Very good fiction too....
review_full: I was intrigued by the name of this restaurant; Captain Alatriste is a character in a series of books - historical fiction. He is a swordsman who is for hire, and also will train you; kind of a Paladin like character. Very good fiction too. It turns out the restaurant is indeed named after the character; the owner has a room in the lower level with copies of the author's books in various languages. The retaurant is as good as the fiction; great blood sausage appetizer. very good house wine, terrific suckling pig and oxtail. This was our splurge restaurant in Madrid and still was not expensive compared to London, New Yourk or even Chicago. Highly recommended.

review_preview: My husband and I went to this quaint little bar last week.  From the street it looked very Spanish and inviting.  We went on several occasions and were very impressed with the range, quality and price of the wines.  The Alma (semi sweet wine) was...
review_full: My husband and I went to this quaint little bar last week. From the street it looked very Spanish and inviting. We went on several occasions and were very impressed with the range, quality and price of the wines. The Alma (semi sweet wine) was my favourite. With each drink a little tapa is given and you can also order bigger portions which you then pay for. The little bar was very atmospheric with Spaniards coming in for a drink and a tapa after work. The staff (it is a family run bar) were amazing. The two men were very friendly and their mother was a real lady who takes an obvious pride in the food she produces. This place is so authentic and such an experience and I can't wait until I return.

title_review: Official: the best grilled octopus we've ever had
review_preview: It was the best meal we'd had in a while. We stumbled upon this restaurant while walking around La Latina during lunch hourls - it was almost empty and I guess they were getting ready to close for siesta. I am glad we had a...
review_full: It was the best meal we'd had in a while. We stumbled upon this restaurant while walking around La Latina during lunch hourls - it was almost empty and I guess they were getting ready to close for siesta. I am glad we had a chance to eat lunch there - the food is truly delicious, big portions and high quality fresh ingredients. We had grilled octopus, grilled vegetables and lamb chops fest - everything was top-notch. Finished up with a dessert of lemon sorbet in cava - amazing. When in Madrid again - definetely coming back for dinner. I guess the place gets very vibrant at night. I would recommend it for a special occasion or just treat yourself to great food while on vacation in this beautiful city. And remember - grilled octopus!!! - a must!

Very nicely presented, a few minor mixups from staff clearly trying hard to please. Service was swift. Quality of food was very good and nicely presented. Good sized portions. I agree with other reviewers it might be a bit pricey if there were no discount but I'd consider going again and recommend it. Oh and the cod as well as miso soup were delicious.We also had Thai chicken curry (huge portion). California rolls, dumplings, crispy duck and sweet and sour lubina. Dessert crepes were huge....we're grateful to have been accomodated for the discount to be able to discover this place in the busy Xmas season and a Saturday night (I called night before). We parked in a indoor spacious parking 60 m away as well. So stress free to get to.

We ordered a Chinese mushroom mix, sauteed spinach, spring rolls, steamed dumplings ... and then followed by Japanese sushi of various kinds. Everything was extremely elegantly served and tasty at 100%. They must have some good chefs in that kitchen! We were served quickly and the restaurant was stylish, clean and quiet. Apparently it has opened recently in September 2015. The location is also great, only 3-4 minutes walk from the San Bernando métro station at Calle Sandoval, 18. Highly recommended!

This is a nice, good quality restaurant with a bit of a boring salad problem!! Otherwise, I recommend it!

title_review: Surprisingly sophisticated with excellent food and service
review_preview: While exploring the Cava Street area of tapas bars and restaurants, and expecting a Monday evening to be a lighter crowd, my wife and I were surprised and intimidated by the large crowds of cruising young people going from bar to bar and restaurant to...
review_full: While exploring the Cava Street area of tapas bars and restaurants, and expecting a Monday evening to be a lighter crowd, my wife and I were surprised and intimidated by the large crowds of cruising young people going from bar to bar and restaurant to restaurant. It was quite a scene! So when we saw the outside umbrella covered tables at Captain Alatriste, and an open table, we just took it, happy to get off our feet and have a place for a relaxing dinner. We were not expecting much by way of quality because of the scene that surrounded us, but we were happily surprised. The white cloth tables often are a cover for expensive food of dubious quality, but here, the environment was proper and predictive. The service is attentive and knowledgeable and they do not try to hurry you.  My wife got the roast suckling pig, which she had been looking for for 3 days, and it lived up to expectations. Perfectly done: juicy with crisp crackling. I do not want to overlook the amuse-bouche of a plate of small chicheron, which were the best I ever had. I know this sounds like a high fat place, suitable for a heart attack, but it has many seafood choices as well. The prices are reasonable and the wine is good and inexpensive. Such a pleasant place in pleine aire on a nice night is unforgetable.

title_review: Second Grand Restaurant visited in Spain
review_preview: We dined here on the second day of our four-day meeting in Alcalá de Henares, a community just outside Madrid.  The plan was to take a bus to the city together, walk about and then meet for dinner. I fell asleep in my hotel room,...
review_full: We dined here on the second day of our four-day meeting in Alcalá de Henares, a community just outside Madrid. The plan was to take a bus to the city together, walk about and then meet for dinner. I fell asleep in my hotel room, an affect no doubt of the lunch time wine, and missed the bus. However, following a few tips from the hotel staff, found my way to the bus and for € 3.6 made it to a Metro stop, which for another € 1, got me to the central Sol Plaza. From there, I was told it was a few blocks to the restaurant's address.  I eventually found my crew camped outside a café off some side street in downtown Madrid. And after a few rounds, we proceeded to the Taberna.  It was a very classic setting, in an underground cellar with foundations probably dating to the Renaissance.  I once again had the seafood dish. But memories of it are now distant, except that I was happy for the most part and enjoyed the company of my colleagues. And, of course, the wine that flowed freely was fine.

title_review: Attractive setting not matched by the food
review_preview: At the tail end of September it was still warm enough to eat outside in the evening and wandering towards the Cava Baja area we were attracted by the softly lit terrace outside this traditional taberna.  If you are seeking peaceful and away from the...
review_full: At the tail end of September it was still warm enough to eat outside in the evening and wandering towards the Cava Baja area we were attracted by the softly lit terrace outside this traditional taberna. If you are seeking peaceful and away from the touristy tapa scrum then this could be as good as you would wish for in the centre of Madrid. However even with peaceful it is good to have some life in the form of fellow diners and passers-by, and this was short on both. All would have been forgiven had the food been as good as the prices implied. Sadly the smart presentation was not matched by the quality of the cooking. Another reviewer called it “insipid” and that is as good a word as any. For the main course, my wife had their Rape a la Bilbaina, which was large in size but bland in the extreme. It came substantially undercooked and had to be sent back; this took quite a while, by which time my unexciting Jarrete de Cordero was getting cold. The waiter seemed disinterested and no apologies were forthcoming.  A disappointing start to our stay in Madrid. Happily things got a lot better over the next few days

review_full: First things first: it's expensive. Now that you know this I can tell you that I enjoyed my dinner here, not only for the food, but especially for the environment. This is an elegant restaurant developed on two levels (ground and underground/cellar) all in the style of the 17th century and inspired or dedicated to the character of Capitàn Alatriste (portrayed in a series of books by Arturo Perez-Reverte) and more generally to the swordsmen of that era. Everything is in place, and everything is very well kept. The menu's wrapped in (fake?) leather, good cutlery, good thick and large serviettes, etc. The food was pretty good, we had starters, main course (pork meat and fish) and dessert. They also have a pretty good choice of wines, but they are rather expensive. The service is great, all very well coordinated. The dining rooms are spacious and charmingly decorated. The paid attention also to the toilets, which are pretty cool. In general I recommend it, but be ready to spend some money.

title_review: High Quality Restaurant with Outdoor Seating
review_preview: Situated about a ten minute stroll from the plaza mayor, the taberna is a large restaurant with limited outdoor seating. We arrived at 23.00 and there was a table outside available but would recommend booking. The restaurant was not as "touristy" as some closer to...
review_full: Situated about a ten minute stroll from the plaza mayor, the taberna is a large restaurant with limited outdoor seating. We arrived at 23.00 and there was a table outside available but would recommend booking. The restaurant was not as "touristy" as some closer to the plaza, but the service was friendly, attentive and professional. The speciality suckling pig was, unsurprisingly, unavailabe at the time we arrived but both the steak and the grilled sea bass that we ordered were cooked to perfection. The wine list is extensive and caters for all tastes and budget. We had a thoroughly enjoyable meal at a reasonable price considering the proximity to the plaza mayor, and will definitely return to try the suckling pig!

review_full: We had much fun attending the 9pm dinner where we were entertained by talented opera singers. Our evening ended with a cava toast for the new year (on January 16th) and a conga dance around the restaurant with fellow diners. However be very careful of what you order and request a English menu. We chose the mid range pre fix (~ 35E) that included 6 different plates between us). Two of the 4 savory plates included baby eels. The entrees had what tasted like canned sauces. Ice cream was a safe dessert option and my husband liked his apple pie. The restaurant has a great tradition that we completely support. The menu options are too ambitious to carry off. Less would be more in this case.

The waiter attending my table realised I did not know about the late schedule and even offered me a licor, so I could stay and watch the whole perfomace. Very nice of him. Also the manager, a sweet smile woman who I did not ask the name, was always approching me and the other guests to chat and make sure we were all enjoying the night.  Once the performaces started the moment was bliss. An experience really worth having. The singers are so entusiastic and connected with the people. Specially a slim bold guy who was in charge of anouncing the celebrations of the night. Like a couple celabrating their 50th wedding aniversary.  I had the Verdi menu. From it I had the salmon rolls and the langoustine as main. The food was simple, but tasty. I guess if you eat all kinds of meat you can vary more than me.  The entertainment finishes about 1 am in a very happy fashion. Go there and see it!

I found the staff friendly and efficient, and as I was dining solo I was placed at a table near other diners, but not so that I felt conspicuous and alone.  The entertainment was wonderful and didn't finish until after midnight.  The restaurant is a little out of the way, but was only a 15 minute walk from my hotel,  and doesn't open until 9pm - so don't arrive early like I did - I had to spend an hour walking around the area to fill in time. The staff ordered a taxi for me to get back to my hotel.

title_review: Excellent food, attentive service, and shady outside eating

I had the Cochinillo Asado (roast suckling pig), described by the waiter as the house special - and it was simply delicious. We enjoyed the meal so much we returned later in the week and were not disappointed; we skipped the entrees on the second occasion as their serves are generous. They also have a good wine list.

title_review: All the right ingredients for a great restaurant
review_preview: We recently had lunch here on a hot, summer afternoon. Initially attracted by the shady patio on a quiet corner, we relaxed with a glass of wine and watched the locals returning home from their morning shopping in La Latina. As always in Madrid, you...
review_full: We recently had lunch here on a hot, summer afternoon. Initially attracted by the shady patio on a quiet corner, we relaxed with a glass of wine and watched the locals returning home from their morning shopping in La Latina. As always in Madrid, you are never hurried by the staff to free up the table. The service was so polite, friendly and professional that we decided to stay for lunch and tried a few different dishes. All were very good and even the house wine was recommendable. Considering the quality of the food and wine and the lovely service and ambience, the prices were very reasonable. We will return and try dinner next time.

review_preview: Although a challenge to find, the evening was well worth the effort.  Our choice of a fixed price meal at 35E each was perfect,  and provided us with the best dinner we had in Madrid!  About half way through our meal the entertainment began.  The...
review_full: Although a challenge to find, the evening was well worth the effort. Our choice of a fixed price meal at 35E each was perfect, and provided us with the best dinner we had in Madrid!  About half way through our meal the entertainment began. The classically trained singing wait staff would intermittently sing a variety of songs, arias, duets and a quartet. They all had wonderful voices, and related well to the audience. Despite the rather small number of guests present, the program was presented with enthusiasm and clear joy. Something special was in store the night we were there, as members of the Madrid Opera were among the diners, and joined in providing a musical treat! Two suggestions that might improve the dinner show: 1. Have the nonsinging wait staff respond more promptly to diners' requests. We had to wait and repeatedly ask for simple things. 2. Begin the main program a bit earlier. Our set dining time was 9:00, and early diners might find a show ending around midnight to be pushing things a bit!

review_preview: Opera....this restaurant is in a back street in Madrid, when we arrived in the taxi we thought the restaurant was closed, as it is very small and doesn't look that inviting. We entered and because we were early we were invited to sit in the...
review_full: Opera....this restaurant is in a back street in Madrid, when we arrived in the taxi we thought the restaurant was closed, as it is very small and doesn't look that inviting. We entered and because we were early we were invited to sit in the bar, which was a bit basic. Another couple and their children turned up and got out of the taxi and their faces said it all, they also thought it was looking closed. A few of the staff turned up, one man looked like the cleaner and a lady who was an older waitress. At 9pm we were told it was open so we were taken into a back room which was the restaurant. It was much nicer than the bar area. The man who looked like a cleaner served our drinks and the waitress and another waitress and the cook served the starter, then they stood around a piano which was in the dining room and sang opera......it was magnificent. Between songs they served us. The meal was superb. I would recommend it to everyone, even if you are not an opera lover, which I wasnt, it was a most memorable night, and not overly expensive.

review_preview: We were initially disappointed to learn that La Posada de la Villa, our favorite restaurant in Madrid, was completely booked for lunch last Sunday.  The maitre d' kindly took us around the corner to La Taberna del Capitan Alatriste, another restaurant of the same owners....
review_full: We were initially disappointed to learn that La Posada de la Villa, our favorite restaurant in Madrid, was completely booked for lunch last Sunday. The maitre d' kindly took us around the corner to La Taberna del Capitan Alatriste, another restaurant of the same owners. They, fortunately, could accomodate us. The food was delicious and served with flair and professionalism. I had the cochinillo asado (roast suckling pig), which was perfectly done -- crisp skin, juicy meaty cut. Others had delicious baby lamb chops and melt-in-your-mouth cola de toro. The tarta de Flandes, the house dessert, was light and tasty. I'd probably still rate Posada de la Villa ahead of Capitan Alatriste, but I'd certainly recommend Capitan Alatriste on its own merits as worthy of a repeat visit next time we're in Madrid.

title_review: Amazing food and service in the heart of Madrid!!!!
review_preview: A great combination of American style food with a modern Spanish influence. The menu isn´t huge but has a great variety of both cultures most popular dishes to satisfly everyones taste buds. My favorite dishes are served on Saturday and Sunday only...BRUNCH!!! From 12:00-17:00 they...
review_full: A great combination of American style food with a modern Spanish influence. The menu isn´t huge but has a great variety of both cultures most popular dishes to satisfly everyones taste buds. My favorite dishes are served on Saturday and Sunday only...BRUNCH!!! From 12:00-17:00 they offer American style brunch that is to die for!!! I usually order the Eggs Bendict with (crispy) bacon and avacado (8,50 Euro). I have ordered other dishes such as Huevos Rancheros and Frech Toast only to be amazed by these dishes as well. Don´t let me forget about the 1 Euro Mimosas and 5 Euro house made bloody Marys. If you are in the mood for a hamburger then go no further. They offer a variety of differnet burgers, all with fresh ingerdients (7,50-8,50 Euro). The burger meat is flavorful and always cooked perfectly to order. The potatoes are hand cut and never frozen (you will be able to taste the differnece immediately).They stay close to their Spanish roots and offer many typical Spanish plates...my favorite being the Cecina de León ( beef salted, smoked and air-dried in the province of León for over nine months). The tostas are very moderately priced with fresh ingredients. My favorite is the avacado, mushroom and parmesan, but if I am really hungry I get the lacón (a delicious Spanish ham) with melted provolone cheese and quail eggs...amazing!!! They have Spanish and American style sandwiches that are huge and cheap. My girlfriend likes the smoked Salmon salad with pears and ginger dressing. I have lived in Spain for 2 years and traveled to most parts of Europe, and I would have to say that this is by far my favorite bar/restaurant. The service is always fast and friendly. The owner speaks perfect English and brings the kind of service you would expect in America to Spain...and trust me that is not easy to find!!!  One tip I would like to provide is that if you decide to come for Brunch, then it never hurts to call ahead and reserve a table because I am personally watching the popularity grow week by week. I don´t want to bore you with more and more information...you just need to go and try it for yourself and you will understand my enthusiasm!!!

review_preview: Went with a friend at her suggestion for Sunday brunch.  The space is small, but it's a friendly atmosphere and the owner (a Tucson native!) and all of the staff are friendly and warm.  Both my friend and I grew up in Tucson, AZ so...
review_full: Went with a friend at her suggestion for Sunday brunch. The space is small, but it's a friendly atmosphere and the owner (a Tucson native!) and all of the staff are friendly and warm. Both my friend and I grew up in Tucson, AZ so it was great to come to a place owned by Tucsonans that also catered to American tastes. My friend got the huevos rancheros (legitimately spicy--which is often hard to find in Spain) and I got French toast with bacon and eggs. The price is great for everyone (when we went, it was packed full of Americans in Spain teaching English and Fulbrighters-- so it's definitely budget-friendly for students). My friend and I paid less than 10 euros for our own meals-- and the staff is more than happy to split the check for groups.  Can't wait to come back to Madrid in the Spring--I'll definitely hit up Carmencita again!

I go there are least 3 times a month, Marianne is always gracious and works very hard to make her business great.

review_preview: If you want to experience a delicious brunch please try this restaurant. It is a bit out of the way and has very specific hours but don't let that keep you from dining here. We had reservations at 11 on a Saturday morning.Our niece took...
review_full: If you want to experience a delicious brunch please try this restaurant. It is a bit out of the way and has very specific hours but don't let that keep you from dining here. We had reservations at 11 on a Saturday morning.Our niece took us here. They have mimosas and eggs bennedict that are out of this world. I would guess there are at least 12 options of the eggs. . The place is small so I would highly recommend reservations. Overall a very quaint place with great food.

review_preview: This was my final night of a solo trip to Madrid and I like to finish with a nice dinner so when I read about La Castifiore, I made a booking. I was there on a weekday evening so the restaurant wasn't full (probably about...
review_full: This was my final night of a solo trip to Madrid and I like to finish with a nice dinner so when I read about La Castifiore, I made a booking.  I was there on a weekday evening so the restaurant wasn't full (probably about 20 diners in the building) but had a thoroughly enjoyable time. Even though I was dining alone, I was made to feel very welcome by the staff.  The food was excellent - delicious pasta stuffed with pear and gorgonzola and excellent duck with very thinly fried potatoes plus an excellent chocolate and almond cake. The entertainment complemented the food. I'm far from an opera buff (and some of the songs I didn't know - there were a few at the end that are so well known, you don't need to be a classical music fan) but the 4 performers were all excellent and engage with the diners.  The evening ended with a famous brindisi (drinking song) being performed along with a complementary glass of white. Well actually the night ended to a rather iconic, non-operatic song being played and the whole restaurant getting up and dancing to it which isn't something that happens at every restaurant. This isn't the cheapest restaurant in Madrid but the food was excellent and the entertainment was first class.

title_review: And a good time was had by all
review_preview: La Castafiore is an unusual--and extremely pleasant--find. Although opera is hardly the first type of entertainment that one associates with Madrid, La Castafiore has turned a pretty standard restaurant into dinner theatre. The waiters burst out every so often into famous arias, sometimes solo, sometimes...
review_full: La Castafiore is an unusual--and extremely pleasant--find. Although opera is hardly the first type of entertainment that one associates with Madrid, La Castafiore has turned a pretty standard restaurant into dinner theatre. The waiters burst out every so often into famous arias, sometimes solo, sometimes in duets, etc. Although I am not an expert, the singing seemed first rate to me, and the evening was simply great, touristy fun. As a restaurant, the review is more mixed, as my seafood brochette was quite good but my wife's cod was absolutely drowned in sauce. If you are looking for fine food, take a pass. But if you are looking for a decent meal and a really kitschy fun experience that defines the evening, this is the place to be.

review_preview: Carmencita Bar is written up in all the travel  reviews and even in some local “what locals do” blogs. I suppose there is a reason. The food is good. Ok. Good. Not great. There are some locals, so there is a hip vibe, to a...
review_full: Carmencita Bar is written up in all the travel reviews and even in some local “what locals do” blogs. I suppose there is a reason. The food is good. Ok. Good. Not great. There are some locals, so there is a hip vibe, to a point. So many reviews in the travel guides has made this a tourist haunt which detracts from the ambiance. We just waited a half hour for a table. Perfectly reasonable given Carmencita’s popularity. But then we also waited an hour for our food. The table behind us, which arrived at least fifteen minutes after us, was done with their meal before we were even served. After no server had visited our area of the restaurant for twenty minutes, walked out with an “hasta luego” and an, oh, by the way, we’d be happy to pay our bill (happy is a relative term) if you’d like to give us the check. Servers are certainly pleasant and doing their best, but the whole thing just doesn’t work. Long story short, if you want to hang out with a bunch of Americans in Madrid, eat a relatively good brunch, and are patient enough to deal with what I think is fair to call a “service ordeal”, this is your place. As cool as the place is billed, I won’t be back.

title_review: Singing was incredible but they need to work on food
review_preview: Obviously this place is about the opera singing. And that was truly incredible. The food needs to be worked on, desperately.  I had the crab cakes which looked more like a meatloaf but didn’t taste very good. Other family members had the pasta which was...
review_full: Obviously this place is about the opera singing. And that was truly incredible.  The food needs to be worked on, desperately. I had the crab cakes which looked more like a meatloaf but didn’t taste very good. Other family members had the pasta which was okay. I had the duck for dinner which was sub par. It was served with “potatoes” which in this case was canned potato sticks. My wife had the fish (bacalow) which was undercooked (3 at the table, all undercooked). The dessert was the highlight and that was average at best. I had an chocolate fudge cake with almonds - which was good. Other desserts - apple tartin, ice cream, and a condensed milk dessert - were also good.  The plate-ware, the glass-ware and the general decor of the restaurant all need to be worked on.  Our server brought the appetizers out and then the other three apps came five minutes later. The same thing happened for dinner and dessert. So three for three (or really zero for three) on the service.  Our dinner was supposed to start at 9 pm. They weren’t ready until about 930 pm. We left the restaurant at about 1 am. I have to think that more than an hour of the experience was singing - maybe 15 or more songs that were about five minutes each. You get a lot of singing and entertainment, which again is the highlight and the reason to come here. If you are a foodie and don’t love opera dining, this is not the place for you.  The singing experience is so extraordinary that I feel bad giving this review. I don’t believe Madrid is known for the cuisine but new lows were reached here on the food and service. The singing made up for much of the flaws but if they could get the food and service a bit better this restaurant would be the coolest dining experience in Europe.

review_preview: We'd been turned away from Sobrino de Botin which had a wait of over an hour for a table and were disappointed as we really wanted some suckling pig for dinner, We came across this unassuming looking restaurant just off the la Calle Cava Baja...
review_full: We'd been turned away from Sobrino de Botin which had a wait of over an hour for a table and were disappointed as we really wanted some suckling pig for dinner, We came across this unassuming looking restaurant just off the la Calle Cava Baja in the Latina district and decided to give it a whirl. On entering the decor was very rustic, good table linen and the walls hung with hunting and bull-fighting scenes, a lovely ambience. Our menu choice was a no-brainer,..they had suckling pig, and it was delicious!  The waiting staff were discreet but friendly and helpful, steering us towards their house wine on the expensive wine-list. It was very good. Desserts were excellent too, and though not inexpensive the meal and experience was absolutely worth the money. In fact it was so good we really didn't care that we'd been unable to eat at "The oldest restaurant in continuous operation in the world!" We had a lovely evening.

This isn’t cheap, just one course with a bottle of wine at €30 and the bill came to almost €100. Be aware that if you eat the bread you are charged. We checked the bill and the bread is charged for but they did deduct it when we told them we hadn’t eaten it!

The menu in English and Spanish was varied with several house specialities. It was my wife's birthday treat so we enjoyed the fine dining experience. We shared an enormous fresh salad for starters. I had the roast suckling pig which was beautifully cooked and very tender. The house red was exceptionally good value for money. Lovely place in a great part of the old town.

review_full: We had a wonderful lunch here with our friends from Madrid. They reserved a table in the basement, which is made up of 16th century masonry and walls. The service was perfect-friendly, helpful, and they kept the water coming which I loved.  Avoid all the tourist traps that are promoted by traveler reviews and check out this spot. Look at these pictures; what a special place. There is a sheet that the waiter will give you that explains the tavern’s history and how it was a prominent location of the Capitan Alatriste novels. This restaurant is revered by locals and I can see why. Try to reserve a spot in the basement if you can.

review_full: My family and I were in Madrid for a few days before traveling to Malaga. My wife and I ventured out for dinned and decided to try Cava Baja Street since it was close by. We walked up and down again on the street with nothing catching our eye or interest. Just as we were about to exit the area we turned the corner and found La Taberna. One of the staff waived to us to come in - even though they hadn't officially opened for the evening. Well, what an experience. I had Suckling Pig that was literally the best I have ever had...just tremendous. My wife had grilled salmon that was perfectly prepared. Prior to the meal we were served some fresh chicharones which were out of this world. And we shared a dinner salad (with tuna, and the salad is large enough for 2 or 3 people). When done with our meal the waiter convinced us to try the Flinder's Pile - sooooooo rich and sllky. And the staff was excellent the whole evening. What a lucky find.

title_review: Lovely suckling pig but tourism a main driver here
review_preview: We have been to a number of restaurants in Madrid over the last week where we have enjoyed a truly authentic Spanish dining experience. The Capitan Alatriste is something of a dilemma. The restaurant building and the area in which it sits are steeped in...
review_full: We have been to a number of restaurants in Madrid over the last week where we have enjoyed a truly authentic Spanish dining experience. The Capitan Alatriste is something of a dilemma. The restaurant building and the area in which it sits are steeped in history, swashbuckling heroes, sword-fights and derring-do. That is fine, and some bits (but not all) of the restaurant are genuinely old, but there is something of a tourist veneer to the whole experience, which is a pity. That said the service (from non-locals) and food were excellent, particularly the suckling pig which, along with the merluza, are the restaurant's specialities. The wine was fine, but more expensive than it needed to be for Madrid - 20€ for the house wine and up. So we did have a good meal in a pleasant setting, but there were few locals there when we ate - this again suggests that tourists are drawn more by the history than by the food. 91€ for three (main course plus a bottle of house wine).

We ordered the 2012 Dehesa Valquejigoso which was a steal for such a wonderful wine which pared perfectly with the starters and our next course of roasted suckling pig and baked cod. By now we were both too full to attempt the Flanders Pie which we will have to come back for. Both mains were delicious and if you want a comfortable, unpretentious, super friendly restaurant you can't go wrong here.
